pageData.text: Clean drinking water is vital for all human life. In this laboratory, students will learn how freshwater sources interact through the natural processes of the <button class='glossary-text'>hydrosphere</button> (all the water on the planet) and what happens to drinking water supplies when our planet becomes altered by human activities. They will design models of different scenarios that affect the earth’s surface water and <button class='glossary-text'>groundwater</button>. The models will demonstrate overconsumption and drought situations, along with water conditions influenced by point and <button class='glossary-text'>non-point source pollution</button>, to examine human-induced effects on the earth’s <button class='glossary-text'>water cycle</button> and how water can move throughout the lithosphere.

pageData.text: The Ogallala <button class='glossary-text'>Aquifer</button> is one of largest aquifers and sources of freshwater in world. It supplies freshwater to much of the Great Plains, providing not only the drinking water for cities in this area, but also support for the area's main industry, agriculture. The land in this area is intensely farmed, growing approximately 20% of the world's grain and supporting almost 40% of its cattle grazing<sup>1</sup>. Without the Ogallala Aquifer, agriculture would not be sustainable in this area because surface water is relatively rare, and rainfall is limited. In fact, agricultural overuse of surface water in this area was one of the contributing factors to the dust bowl. But, despite its size, this aquifer is in danger. Each year we draw far more water from it than can be replenished in the same timeframe. Additionally, <button class='glossary-text'>recharge zones</button> are rare due to the type of soil in the region and many of these areas have either been threatened or destroyed by converting land for farming or development. To avoid a catastrophe, many agricultural scientists are trying to find ways to grow food more efficiently in the region using less water. Some of these strategies include genetically engineered crops that use less water, planting crops to avoid evaporation, drip irrigation, and protecting and restoring wetlands to allow for more recharge and surface water.

https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2021/12/kansas-aquifer-ogallala-water-crisis-drought/621007/

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>hydrosphere</button> encompasses all the water on the planet. It includes freshwater and saltwater; liquid, solid, and vapor; and water that is above ground and underground. All of these different sources of water interact and transform into one another through processes within the biogeochemical cycle known as the hydrological or <button class='glossary-text'>water cycle</button> (Figure 1). Water falls to the earth as precipitation and runs off the land’s surface; infiltrates the ground; or evaporates from surface waters that include oceans, lakes, and rivers. The evaporated water vapor condenses in the clouds and falls to the earth over time as precipitation. Then the process begins again. The water that has infiltrated the ground, known as <button class='glossary-text'>groundwater</button>, is located in and below the <button class='glossary-text'>water table</button>, which is the top layer of the soil in which groundwater fills most of the pores. In the water table, water is able to enter the ground through unsaturated surface soil voids, filling the soil below this level due to natural gravitational pull. With this natural movement of water, the hydrosphere continuously cycles all phases of water to all parts of the earth.

pageData.text: While water encompasses more than 70% of Earth’s surface, freshwater, which accounts for only 3% of Earth’s water, is the only type of water that is readily accessible for human consumption. However, about a third of that 3%, (just under 1% of Earth's total water) is readily accessible, with the remaining freshwater being held in Earth’s icy regions, which include glaciers and polar ice caps. This is known as the , or the frozen portion of the (Figure 2).

pageData.text: Freshwater available for human use is made up of surface water and <button class='glossary-text'>groundwater</button>. When precipitation falls from the atmosphere to the earth, it becomes part of the environment by either washing across the land and into bodies of water or by <button class='glossary-text'>percolating</button> through the surface of the soil. Here, it can be taken up by plants or filtered deep into the ground. In the latter case, this surface water enters the ground through areas known as <button class='glossary-text'>recharge zones</button>. Water enters these unsaturated zones on the surface of the land by the natural pull of gravity. The <button class='glossary-text'>porosity</button> of a material is a measure of the void spaces in the rocks and soil, and the ability of water to pass through those void spaces is known as <button class='glossary-text'>permeability</button>. This water now enters the groundwater system and saturates the ground beneath. People rely on these zones to recharge <button class='glossary-text'>aquifers</button>. Through the use of wells, people can supply water to their homes.

Deeper into the ground, multiple layers of unsaturated and saturated soil of many different pore sizes and material types exist. Some of these layers are permeable, whereas others are <button class='glossary-text'>impermeable</button>, which means that water cannot easily pass through them. Many types of ground consist of permeable materials, like rocky sediment, fine sand, or soil. Others are made of less permeable materials that impede the percolation of water, such as clay-like dirt, thicker sand, and man-made structures that include paved streets and sidewalks. The types of material that make up the consistency of the ground impacts the ability to access the groundwater.

<button class='glossary-text'>Groundwater</button> can sometimes be accessed by pumping wells placed in <button class='glossary-text'>aquifers</button>. Aquifers are underground basins from which water can be removed at a reasonable rate, with the most ideal aquifers containing many pore spaces for water storage. However, the size, depth, and amount of water within an aquifer can vary greatly, making the process of extracting groundwater from an aquifer a variable as well. While most of the water that humans use is held in the ground, much of it is too deep for humans to access.

pageData.subTitle: Surface Water
pageData.text: The small amount of remaining freshwater accessible for human use is made up of the surface water from lakes, rivers, and ponds as well as the water vapor in the atmosphere (). There are many regions that don’t have access to sources and must rely on reservoirs, such as natural and man-made lakes, as a source of drinking water. With surface water making up a small percentage of freshwater worldwide, events such as droughts or excessive withdrawal from reservoirs within these areas can cause rapid depletion of vital water for highly populated, metropolitan areas that rely on these sources of drinking water. Also, many human-induced factors can lead to inaccessible freshwater. Impervious surfaces such as roads, parking lots, and buildings can limit the quality of accessible water by creating a surface for the runoff of pollutants into nearby bodies of water. Additionally, most water that is withdrawn from a waterway or is returned to the environment, but some is either taken up by plants and animals or lost to evaporation, adding another source of inaccessible freshwater for humans.

To understand how surface water and groundwater affect each other, let’s investigate some of these same scenarios but from a different perspective. For instance, impervious surfaces not only negatively affect the quality of surface water, but they can also block access to and pollute groundwater sources. Also, when excessive water is withdrawn from a groundwater well that is pumping water stored in the <button class='glossary-text'>water table</button>, surface water levels (or stream flow) can be greatly reduced and can ruin the quality of the water. Similarly, pumping water from a freshwater reservoir can lower groundwater levels and possibly cause contamination.

On the positive side, if there is sufficient rainfall in an environment, the water can overflow the land, feeding into marshes, rivers, or lakes. In contrast, if surface water receives excess rainfall, it can run onto and infiltrate the land to become groundwater. All in all, to truly understand the availability of water in a region, understanding the interconnectedness of groundwater and surface water is of vital importance.

pageData.subTitle: Human-Induced Actions that Affect the Water Cycle
pageData.text: There are many ways to limit or contaminate the freshwater available to humans. The overload of substances that are harmful to the environment, known as pollution, is a major issue affecting today’s freshwater supply. It is easier to determine the origin of certain pollutants than others; in turn, it is easier to prevent certain pollutants from occurring in the future than others. is pollution that can be tracked to one specific source. The source of pollution is identifiable and able to be limited if proper action is taken to control the pollutant source. A pipe from a wastewater treatment plant discharging waste into a water source and a person dumping gasoline into a water supply (such as a lake) are examples of point source pollution. Figure 3 shows an example of contaminated run-off from a mine; the distinct blue color is from copper in the water. Many restrictions have been put in place to control waste from industries and wastewater treatment plants, but enforcing them is not an easy task.

If the origin of a pollutant is unknown, it may be difficult to determine how it entered the freshwater supply. usually occurs from the movement of pollutants through a system to a different area, making its origins much harder to discover. When water moves toxic chemicals—such as fertilizers and pesticides, oil, and gasoline—over the ground or through an aquatic system such as a river or stream, the pollutants can move large geographical distances. All these types of pollutants can start in one region and end up many miles away, making this type of pollution very difficult to prevent. Non-point source pollution is also the most prevalent type in the environment, making it extremely important to monitor.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Bright blue water flowing down a rocky hill into a bright blue creek.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Bright blue water flowing down a rocky hill into a bright blue creek.

pageData.text: NOAA Fisheries, NW region, Nick Iadanza

While pollution is a big part of what limits our available freshwater resources, there also are issues with overwithdrawal and overconsumption from <button class='glossary-text'>aquifers</button> and reservoirs. With very few limits set on water usage in most developed countries, people worldwide use water at a rate that is faster than it is able to be replenished in the environment. Although water is recycled through precipitation, evaporation, and runoff in the <button class='glossary-text'>water cycle</button>, there is a need for limits on water usage to ensure that sufficient water supplies are accessible. In a model known as the <button class='glossary-text'>water budget</button>, the inputs, outputs, and storage of water in the environment are calculated and balanced to ensure equal recycling. However, with droughts and excessive withdrawals occurring in many areas around the world, water usage must be monitored and lowered to keep the budget balanced. In the United States, each person uses an average of 150 gallons of water per day; in multiple developing countries, the average person uses fewer than 10 gallons of water per day. Of the large amount of water that is used by the United States, only 13% is used by households. The other 87% is used by industry and for agriculture. Even though it is recognized that there is only a small percentage of freshwater readily available for human consumption, it is still being used at a rate that can lead to dangerously low levels in the near future.
Through the following activities, <button class='glossary-text'>groundwater</button> and surface water models demonstrate the impact of several important factors on drinking water.

In activity 1, you will set up a model of a reservoir and <button class='glossary-text'>aquifer</button> to observe aquifer overdraw. You will use the same model set up in Activity 2.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you’ll learn the importance of the <button class='glossary-text'>water cycle</button> and how withdrawal and recharge are two processes that continuously affect the environment but are not always in a balanced state. You’ll create a model where a drinking water reservoir and a layer of land with <button class='glossary-text'>groundwater</button> wells within it will be separated from each other by an impermeable layer. To help you understand the interconnectedness of the two water systems, you’ll determine different rates of withdrawal and recharge.

pageData.text: Place a block of clay in the plastic container so it is one-third of the total distance away from one side of the container. This piece of clay will act as an <button class='glossary-text'>impermeable</button> retaining rock, so make sure to mold it so that it fits tightly on the sides and on the bottom of the container.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Diagram of the reservoir, clay bar strip, aquifer, and wells
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram of the reservoir, clay bar strip, aquifer, and wells

typeBefore.text: Note: you may want to microwave the clay at 10 seconds intervals until softened to assit in manipulation.

pageData.text: The smaller section will represent the reservoir, and the larger section will be the <button class='glossary-text'>aquifer</button>, as seen in Figure 4.
Take a large clear plastic tube and cut it in half with a pair of scissors. These two cylinders will model wells drilled into the ground to reach the aquifer.
Add just enough sand to cover the bottom of the aquifer section, spreading the sand with your hands to level it out.

Place the two cut plastic tube pieces (wells) upright in the sand near the edge of the container in the aquifer farthest from the clay bar at random areas (see Figure 4). Ensure that each well is seated firmly against the bottom of the container.
Add another layer of sand, making sure to have the sand slightly higher up on one well than the other.

Form the next layer of the aquifer by adding enough gravel to cover the sand while creating a slight incline. Form the top of the incline around the wells. The gravel hill should slope downward toward the retaining wall (clay) and should be even with the top of the clay.

To represent precipitation, poke approximately 10 holes in the bottom of the foam cup and fill it with water (over the model), allowing the water to sprinkle onto the top of the slope, near the edge of the container behind the wells. Some water may leak into the reservoir.
Fill the reservoir with water until the water level rises a few centimeters over the clay retaining wall.
The top of the <button class='glossary-text'>water table</button> is represented by the height of the water in each of the wells.

Insert a straw into one of the wells until it touches the bottom. Hold your forefinger tightly over the open end of the straw to create a seal and then remove the straw from the well. Use the permanent marker to draw a line to mark the top of the water level in the straw. This line represents the top of the water level in the aquifer.

Using a disposable pipet, drain this well by squeezing the round bulb of the pipet, putting the pipet tip into the well, and releasing the bulb to suck up the water. This water can be placed in a cup for disposal. Use the pipet to empty all the water in this well. (There may be a mixture of sand and water removed.)

As soon as you have removed all the water in the well, place the straw back into the bottom of the well and remove a water sample as you did in Step 11. Mark the top of the water column with a permanent marker as before. This represents the level of water in the well after a period of high withdrawal. Record your observations on page 11.

Wait 2 minutes and observe what happens to the drained well. Record your observations in the Lab Notebook. Measure the water level again using the straw and permanent marker, and note in the observations what has changed. Has the magnitude of the water table decreased?
If needed, refill the reservoir with water until the water level rises a few centimeters over the retaining wall (as in Step 9).
Repeat Steps 11 to 14 using the other well.

In Activity 2, you will continue to use the model from Activity 1. You will add a waste discharge pipe and a simulated pollutant to model the effect of <button class='glossary-text'>point source pollution</button> on the reservoir and <button class='glossary-text'>groundwater</button>.

typeBefore.text: For this activity, you will create a model of <button class='glossary-text'>point source pollution</button>: a large industrial plant is disposing of its waste materials through a discharge pipe into a drinking water reservoir. You’ll see how these pollutants play a role within the <button class='glossary-text'>water cycle</button> and if an <button class='glossary-text'>impermeable</button> layer has an effect in blocking contamination of the <button class='glossary-text'>groundwater</button>.

pageData.text: If the water in the reservoir from Activity 1 has a large amount of sand in it, pour it into a bowl and remove any excess sand from the reservoir. Do your best to let only water drain from the <button class='glossary-text'>aquifer</button> section, keeping all other materials (clay, sand, gravel, and tubes) in place.
Take one of the thinner, flexible aquarium tubes and cut it in half. This will act as a discharge pipe from an industrial plant.
Tape the aquarium tube half to the side of the plastic container, making sure the opening is not touching the bottom of the container.
Fill the reservoir with clean water until it is just above the top of the clay.

Take a glass of water and pour a small amount of Kool-Aid<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> drink mix into it (just enough for the water to change color). Mix well. This will represent the waste (pollutant).
Use the 10-mL syringe to suck up the waste.
Attach the end of the syringe to the aquarium tube, and inject the pollutant into the discharge pipe (aquarium tubing) you created.
Observe and record in the Lab Notebook what happens to the water in the reservoir as you pump the waste into the discharge pipe.

Next, insert a straw into one of the wells until it touches the bottom. Hold your forefinger tightly over the open end of the straw to create a seal, and then remove the straw from the well (as in Activity 1) to see if the polluted water has made its way into the groundwater supply.
Wait 1 minute, and repeat observations of the well two more times to verify.
Rinse the 10-mL syringe by drawing freshwater into it and expelling the water into a cup or sink 3 times.

After you’ve completed this activity, obtain a medium- to large-size plastic bowl/container. Take a handful of the gravel and sand mixture. Rinse water through it, separating the gravel (in your hand) from the sand and water mixture (now in the bowl). Place the gravel on a paper towel to the side; let the excess water drain into the bowl, either in a sink or outside on the ground, being careful to retain as much sand as possible in the bowl. Reuse the sand and gravel for Activity 3. If weather permits, you can do this step outside for easier clean up.

In Activity 3, you will set up a model of a confined and an unconfined <button class='glossary-text'>aquifer</button> to model the impact of <button class='glossary-text'>non-point source pollution</button> using a simulated pollutant.

  • a house on a hill, where drinking water comes from a well confined under an layer
  • a house located downhill by a pond, where drinking water comes from a well in a permeable layer
All the land between the two houses is fertilized each year, and both homeowners want to know the effects that this potential pollutant (fertilizer) has on their water source in the event of runoff from rain.

pageData.text: Place the flattened piece of clay on top of the uphill side, and mold it so that it fits tightly around the well (see Figure 8). This will act as an impermeable layer.

pageData.desc: Figure 8: Close up of plastic container with sand higher on an angle in the container, supplemented with a layer of gravel and an added square piece of blue clay
pageData.altText: Figure 8: Close up of plastic container with sand higher on an angle in the container, supplemented with a layer of gravel and an added square piece of blue clay

pageData.text: Top the model with a thin layer of sand, continuing the sloped approach. In the sand/gravel mixture at the bottom of the hill, dig a small circular hole. Pour about a cupful of water into the hole to represent a pond (see Figure 9).

pageData.desc: Figure 9: Plastic container with sand higher on an angle in the container, supplemented with a layer of gravel and an added square piece of blue clay. Model is topped with a thin layer of sand and a hole with water.
pageData.altText: Figure 9: Plastic container with sand higher on an angle in the container, supplemented with a layer of gravel and an added square piece of blue clay. Model is topped with a thin layer of sand and a hole with water.

pageData.text: Take the opened Kool-Aid<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> drink mix packet and sprinkle the remaining contents on the surface of the sloped land. This will act as fertilizer on the landscape.

Put water in the foam cup (without Kool-Aid<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> drink mix), and shake the cup above the land to simulate rain. Observe and record what happens to the fertilizer and how it affects both the <button class='glossary-text'>groundwater</button> and pond water (by tracking the now-colored water).

Wait 30 seconds, and then use the 10-mL syringe to pull water out from the well that is not surrounded by the impermeable clay layer. Observe and record the color of the water that came out of the well along with the pond water color. (Some sediment may be sucked into the syringe during this step.)

Now use the syringe to draw water from the uphill well that is confined by an impermeable layer. Observe and record the color of the water that came from this well. (Some sediment may be sucked into the syringe during this step.)

A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. In Activity 1, set up the model with clay, wells, sand and gravel. Then, fill the reservoir. Next, use the straw to measure the water table in the well, drain the well and remeasure the water table. Wait 2 minutes, then observe and measure the wells. Repeat this for both wells. In activity 2, reset the reservoir. Then, set up the discharge pipe and refill the reservoir with water. Next, make the pollutant mix from the Kool Aid, inject it into the discharge pipe and observe the water in the reservoir. Then, measure the ground water in the wells and observe for polluted water repeating 3 times at 1-minute intervals. Next, reset the model. In activity 3, set up the container with wells, sand, gravel and clay. Then, dig a hole in the sand and add water. Add Kool Aid as fertilizer and water from the cup as rain. Next, observe the movement of color. After 30 seconds, remove water from the upstream and downstream wells and observe.

data.title: Aquifer
data.content: An underground basin from which water can be removed at a reasonable rate

data.title: Cryosphere
data.content: The frozen portion of the hydrosphere

data.title: Groundwater
data.content: Water that exists underground in saturated zones beneath the land surface

data.title: Hydrological cycle
data.content: The movement of water as water molecules through the Earth's surface to the atmosphere and back again; also called the water cycle

data.title: Hydrosphere
data.content: All the water on the planet

data.title: Impermeable
data.content: Describes material that is not permeable to water

data.title: Non-point source pollution
data.content: Pollution that is a result of movement of pollutants through a system to a different area

data.title: Percolating
data.content: Filtering through a porous surface or substance

data.title: Permeability
data.content: The ability of water to pass through the void spaces in the rock or soil

data.title: Point source pollution
data.content: Pollution that can be tracked to one specific source

data.title: Porosity
data.content: A measure of the void spaces in the rocks and soil

data.title: Recharge zone
data.content: An unsaturated zone on the surface of the land where water enters by the natural pull of gravity

data.title: Water budget
data.content: A model that considers inputs, outputs, and storage of water in the environment

data.title: Water table
data.content: The top layer of soil in which groundwater fills most of the pores
